import React, { useState } from 'react'; const Kafka = () => { const [activeFlow, setActiveFlow] = useState(null); const [selectedService, setSelectedService] = useState(null); const [activeTab, setActiveTab] = useState('overview'); // Theory sections const theoryTabs = [ { id: 'overview', label: 'Kafka Overview' }, { id: 'architecture', label: 'Architecture' }, { id: 'concepts', label: 'Core Concepts' }, { id: 'patterns', label: 'Design Patterns' }, { id: 'tradeoffs', label: 'Tradeoffs' } ]; const theoryContent = { overview: (

What is Apache Kafka?

Apache Kafka is a distributed event streaming platform capable of handling trillions of events per day. Originally developed at LinkedIn, it's now an open-source project maintained by the Apache Software Foundation.

Kafka combines three key capabilities:

  • Publish-Subscribe Messaging: Like a message queue or enterprise messaging system
  • Storage System: Stores streams of events durably and reliably
  • Stream Processing: Processes streams of events as they occur
), architecture: (

Kafka Architecture

Kafka's distributed architecture with producers, consumers, brokers, and ZooKeeper

Brokers

Kafka servers that store data and serve clients. A Kafka cluster typically consists of multiple brokers for fault tolerance.

ZooKeeper

Manages cluster metadata and coordinates brokers. Note: Recent versions are removing ZooKeeper dependency (KIP-500).

), concepts: (

Core Kafka Concepts

Topics & Partitions

Topics are categories or feed names to which records are published. Each topic is split into partitions for parallelism. 

{`// Topic with 3 partitions and replication factor 2
bin/kafka-topics.sh --create --topic orders \
--partitions 3 --replication-factor 2 \
--bootstrap-server localhost:9092`}

Producers & Consumers

Producers publish data to topics. Consumers read from topics. Consumer groups allow parallel consumption.

Producer Properties
  • acks: 0/1/all
  • retries
  • batch.size
  • linger.ms
Consumer Properties
  • group.id
  • auto.offset.reset
  • enable.auto.commit
  • max.poll.records

Message Retention

Kafka retains messages for a configurable period (default 7 days) or until size limit is reached. This enables:

  • Replay of events for recovery
  • Event sourcing patterns
  • Batch processing of historical data
), patterns: (

Common Kafka Patterns

Event Sourcing

Store all changes to application state as a sequence of events. The log becomes the source of truth. 

{`// Example event structure
{
  "eventId": "abc123",
  "eventType": "OrderPlaced",
  "timestamp": "2025-05-23T10:30:00Z",
  "aggregateId": "order-789",
  "payload": {
    "customerId": "cust-456",
    "items": [...],
    "total": 99.99
  }
}`}

CQRS (Command Query Responsibility Segregation)

Separate read and write operations. Kafka acts as the event log that synchronizes read models.

Commands → Write Model → Kafka Events → Read Model
↑
Queries ← Read Model

Saga Pattern

Manage distributed transactions across microservices using a sequence of local transactions with compensating actions.

1. Order Service: Place Order → order-events
2. Payment Service: Process Payment → payment-events
3. If payment fails: Compensate → order-cancel-events
), tradeoffs: (

Kafka Tradeoffs

When to Use Kafka

  • High throughput event streaming (100k+ events/sec)
  • Event sourcing architectures
  • Real-time stream processing
  • Microservices communication at scale
  • Need for event replayability

When Not to Use Kafka

  • Simple request-reply patterns
  • Low message volume (1k messages/day)
  • Applications needing strong ordering guarantees across topics
  • When you can't tolerate eventual consistency
  • Limited operational expertise for distributed systems

Alternatives

RabbitMQ

Better for traditional message queues

AWS Kinesis

Managed alternative in AWS

NATS

Lighter weight, lower latency

) }; // E-commerce example data const services = [ { name: 'Order Service', role: 'Producer/Consumer', description: 'Creates orders and publishes OrderPlaced events', topics: { produces: ['order-events'], consumes: [] }, color: 'bg-blue-100 border-blue-300' }, { name: 'Payment Service', role: 'Producer/Consumer', description: 'Processes payments and publishes PaymentProcessed events', topics: { produces: ['payment-events'], consumes: ['order-events'] }, color: 'bg-green-100 border-green-300' }, { name: 'Inventory Service', role: 'Producer/Consumer', description: 'Updates stock and publishes InventoryUpdated events', topics: { produces: ['inventory-events'], consumes: ['order-events'] }, color: 'bg-yellow-100 border-yellow-300' }, { name: 'Shipping Service', role: 'Producer/Consumer', description: 'Initiates shipments and publishes ShipmentInitiated events', topics: { produces: ['shipping-events'], consumes: ['payment-events'] }, color: 'bg-purple-100 border-purple-300' }, { name: 'Notification Service', role: 'Consumer/Producer', description: 'Sends notifications and publishes EmailSent/SMSSent events', topics: { produces: ['notification-events'], consumes: ['order-events', 'payment-events', 'shipping-events'] }, color: 'bg-pink-100 border-pink-300' } ]; const topics = [ { name: 'order-events', events: ['OrderPlaced', 'OrderCancelled'], color: 'bg-blue-50' }, { name: 'payment-events', events: ['PaymentProcessed', 'PaymentFailed'], color: 'bg-green-50' }, { name: 'inventory-events', events: ['StockUpdated', 'OutOfStock'], color: 'bg-yellow-50' }, { name: 'shipping-events', events: ['ShipmentInitiated', 'ShipmentDelivered'], color: 'bg-purple-50' }, { name: 'notification-events', events: ['EmailSent', 'SMSSent'], color: 'bg-pink-50' } ]; const flowSteps = [ { step: 1, service: 'Order Service', action: 'Customer places order → OrderPlaced event sent to order-events topic', active: false }, { step: 2, service: 'Payment Service', action: 'Consumes OrderPlaced → Processes payment → Sends PaymentProcessed to payment-events', active: false }, { step: 3, service: 'Inventory Service', action: 'Consumes OrderPlaced → Updates stock → Sends InventoryUpdated to inventory-events', active: false }, { step: 4, service: 'Shipping Service', action: 'Consumes PaymentProcessed → Initiates shipment → Sends ShipmentInitiated to shipping-events', active: false }, { step: 5, service: 'Notification Service', action: 'Consumes multiple events → Sends notifications → Publishes EmailSent/SMSSent', active: false } ]; const handleFlowDemo = () => { setActiveFlow(0); flowSteps.forEach((_, index) => { setTimeout(() => { setActiveFlow(index); }, index * 1500); }); setTimeout(() => { setActiveFlow(null); }, flowSteps.length * 1500); }; return (

Apache Kafka Deep Dive

Distributed event streaming platform for building real-time, scalable, and fault-tolerant systems

{/* Theory Section */}
{theoryTabs.map((tab) => ( ))}
{theoryContent[activeTab]}
{/* E-commerce Example Section */}

E-commerce Case Study

Below is an example of how Kafka can be used in an e-commerce system to create a loosely coupled, event-driven architecture that scales with demand.

{/* Interactive Flow Demo */}

Order Processing Flow

{flowSteps.map((step, index) => (
{step.step}

{step.service}

{step.action}

))}
{/* Services and Topics */}

Microservices

{services.map((service, index) => (
setSelectedService(selectedService === index ? null : index)} >

{service.name}

{service.description}

{service.role}
Produces: {service.topics.produces.length}
Consumes: {service.topics.consumes.length}
{selectedService === index && (
Produces Topics:
{service.topics.produces.map((topic, i) => ( {topic} ))}
Consumes Topics:
{service.topics.consumes.map((topic, i) => ( {topic} ))}
)}
))}

Kafka Topics

{topics.map((topic, index) => (

{topic.name}

{topic.events.map((event, i) => ( {event} ))}
))}

Sample Event Structure

{`{
  "eventId": "evt_12345",
  "eventType": "OrderPlaced",
  "timestamp": "2025-05-23T10:30:00Z",
  "aggregateId": "order-789",
  "payload": {
    "customerId": "cust-456",
    "items": [
      {"productId": "prod-1", "quantity": 2},
      {"productId": "prod-2", "quantity": 1}
    ],
    "totalAmount": 99.99
  },
  "metadata": {
    "source": "order-service",
    "correlationId": "corr-abc123"
  }
}`}
{/* Implementation Section */}

Implementation Guide

Producer Configuration

{`# Producer properties (application.properties)
spring.kafka.producer.bootstrap-servers=localhost:9092
spring.kafka.producer.key-serializer=org.apache.kafka.common.serialization.StringSerializer
spring.kafka.producer.value-serializer=org.springframework.kafka.support.serializer.JsonSerializer
spring.kafka.producer.acks=all
spring.kafka.producer.retries=3
spring.kafka.producer.batch-size=16384
spring.kafka.producer.linger-ms=5`}

Consumer Configuration

{`# Consumer properties (application.properties)
spring.kafka.consumer.bootstrap-servers=localhost:9092
spring.kafka.consumer.group-id=payment-group
spring.kafka.consumer.auto-offset-reset=earliest
spring.kafka.consumer.key-deserializer=org.apache.kafka.common.serialization.StringDeserializer
spring.kafka.consumer.value-deserializer=org.springframework.kafka.support.serializer.JsonDeserializer
spring.kafka.consumer.enable-auto-commit=false
spring.kafka.consumer.max-poll-records=500`}

Producer Example

{`@Service
public class OrderService {

  private final KafkaTemplate kafkaTemplate;

  public void placeOrder(Order order) {
    // Business logic
    OrderEvent event = new OrderEvent(
      UUID.randomUUID().toString(),
      "OrderPlaced",
      Instant.now(),
      order.getId(),
      order
    );
    
    // Send with callback
    ListenableFuture> future = 
      kafkaTemplate.send("order-events", order.getId(), event);
    
    future.addCallback(
      result -> log.info("Event sent: {}", result),
      ex -> log.error("Failed to send event", ex)
    );
  }
}`}

Consumer Example

{`@Service
public class PaymentService {

  @KafkaListener(topics = "order-events", groupId = "payment-group")
  public void processOrderEvent(
    @Payload OrderEvent event,
    @Header(KafkaHeaders.RECEIVED_KEY) String key,
    @Header(KafkaHeaders.RECEIVED_PARTITION) int partition,
    @Header(KafkaHeaders.OFFSET) long offset,
    Acknowledgment ack) {
    
    if ("OrderPlaced".equals(event.getEventType())) {
      try {
        // Process payment
        Payment payment = processPayment(event);
        
        // Send payment event
        PaymentEvent paymentEvent = createPaymentEvent(payment);
        kafkaTemplate.send("payment-events", payment.getId(), paymentEvent);
        
        // Manually commit offset
        ack.acknowledge();
      } catch (Exception e) {
        log.error("Payment processing failed", e);
        // Will be retried due to manual offset commit
      }
    }
  }
}`}

Best Practices

Schema Evolution

Use Schema Registry (Avro/Protobuf) for backward/forward compatibility as your events evolve.

Idempotent Consumers

Design consumers to handle duplicate messages safely (idempotent operations).

Dead Letter Queues

Implement DLQ for messages that fail processing after retries.

Monitoring

Monitor consumer lag, broker metrics, and topic growth.

Partitioning Strategy

Choose partition keys carefully to ensure even distribution and ordering guarantees.

Security

Implement SSL, SASL, and ACLs in production environments.

); }; export default Kafka;
